Peter Frederick Strawson (1919–2006) was an important and
influential philosopher of the late twentieth century.  His writings
range over philosophical logic, the philosophy of language,
metaphysics, epistemology and the history of philosophy.  Across these
debates, Strawson aimed to identify the most fundamental concepts
involved in our ordinary ways of thinking. He took these to include
such core concepts as those of body, person, space and time, and
causation. Strawson aimed to show both that sceptical challenges to
our use of such concepts are spurious and unwarranted and also that
our entitlement to use these concepts does not depend on their being
reduced to some supposedly more naturalistically acceptable basis,
such as experience as conceived of by the empiricists, or the concepts
involved in fundamental science. According to Strawson, the proper task
of metaphysics is to describe these indispensable notions and their
interconnections. His work was influential in moving Oxford philosophy
away from the anti-metaphysical work of A.J. Ayer and J.L. Austin
towards a re-engagement with many traditional philosophical questions.
Strawson’s work continues to command attention.
